Situation1: A minor misunderstanding about weekend plans just arose.
Expectation2: Maintain client confidentiality and ethical standards
Situation2: During a casual networking event, someone casually asks about the nature of a client’s case.
Story: I stood in the corner of the crowded bar, my phone buzzing in my pocket. It was Mia, my girlfriend, texting about our weekend plans. She thought I’d promised to spend Saturday with her, but I’d mentioned a work event. Her messages grew sharper, frustration seeping through the screen. I knew I should call her, clear things up, and reassure her—she always said I was good at resolving our little conflicts. But just as I started typing, a colleague’s friend sidled up, drink in hand, and asked, “So, what’s that big case you’re working on? Must be juicy, right?” I felt the familiar tug of professional duty—client confidentiality was non-negotiable, even in casual conversation. My mind raced, torn between the expectation to be a supportive boyfriend and the ethical standards of my profession. I could feel the pressure mounting, my heart pounding as I weighed my next move, caught between two worlds that suddenly felt impossibly far apart.
